marketNews.title: MSCI: Barito Renewables Energy, Petrosea, and Petrindo Jaya Kreasi Will Not Be Included in February 2025 Review
marketNews.content: MSCI announced that Barito Renewables Energy (BREN), Petrindo Jaya Kreasi (CUAN), and Petrosea (PTRO) will not be included in the MSCI Indonesia Investable Market Index review for February 2025 after analysis and input regarding potential investability constraints. The MSCI February 2025 index review announcement is scheduled for 11 February 2025. In response, BREN President Director Hendra Tan said the MSCI decision is entirely the authority of the index provider and beyond the company's control, and that BREN will continue to focus on sustainable growth. Previously, BREN was removed from the FTSE Global Equity Series – Large Cap by FTSE Russell on 19 September 2024, just one month after its inclusion, due to free‑float issues caused by a high concentration of ownership, with 97% of shares held by four shareholders. BREN's share price fell from 11,025 rupiah on 19 September 2024 to 7,225 rupiah on 22 September 2024, a decline of 34%. Nevertheless, BREN clarified to the Indonesia Stock Exchange on 22 September 2024 that the number of shares meeting the free‑float requirement was 15.6 billion shares, or 11.66% of the total shares outstanding on 19 September 2024, which is not significantly different from the prospectus free‑float of 11.73%. Following today's MSCI announcement on Friday (7/2), the three stocks closed lower, with BREN down 19.94%, CUAN down 19.96%, and PTRO down 24.61%. MSCI stated that it will continue to review the eligibility of these stocks in future index reviews and will provide further communication as needed.

marketNews.title: MDKA FY24: Gold Sales Volume -16.5% YoY, Copper +9% YoY
marketNews.content:
- $MDKA: Merdeka Copper Gold reported a gold production volume of 35,824 ounces in Q4 2024 (+17.3% QoQ, +21.4% YoY) and a gold sales volume of 29,056 ounces (+4.6% QoQ, -6.8% YoY). Copper production reached 3,419 tons in Q4 2024 (-10.3% QoQ, +0.6% YoY) with copper sales of 3,101 tons (-37.6% QoQ, +40.6% YoY). These results bring total 2024 gold production to 115,867 ounces (-16.4% YoY) and copper production to 13,902 tons (+9.4% YoY), in line with management guidance. Total 2024 gold sales were 108,471 ounces (-16.5% YoY) and copper sales 14,411 tons (+9% YoY). MDKA announced 2025 guidance of gold production around 100,000‑110,000 ounces and copper production around 11,000‑13,000 tons.
- $MBMA: Merdeka Battery Materials reported Q4 2024 production of 3.4 million wet metric tons (wmt) of limonite nickel ore (-8.1% QoQ, +110% YoY) and 3.0 million wmt of saprolite nickel ore (+200% QoQ, +108% YoY). Nickel pig iron production reached 18,823 tons in Q4 2024 (+35.4% QoQ, -16.2% YoY) and high‑grade nickel matte production was 11,893 tons (-9.8% QoQ, +1.6% YoY). These figures bring 2024 nickel pig iron production to 82,161 tons (+26.2% YoY) and high‑grade nickel matte to 50,315 tons (+65.9% YoY). MBMA announced 2025 guidance of limonite sales 12.5‑15 million wmt, saprolite sales 6‑7 million wmt, nickel pig iron sales 80,000‑87,000 tons, and high‑grade nickel matte sales 50,000‑55,000 tons.
- $PTRO: Petrosea Commissioner Erwin Ciputra purchased 500,000 PTRO shares at an average price of 3,950 rupiah per share on 4 February 2025, totaling approximately 2 billion rupiah. After the transaction, Erwin Ciputra's ownership increased from 0.0729% to 0.0779%.
- $KPIG: The Ministry of Environment ordered MNC Land to temporarily halt the development of the Lido Special Economic Zone (KEK) in Bogor, West Java due to water and environmental management issues, citing sedimentation in Lake Lido caused by mismanagement. KPIG stated that the sedimentation occurred before the company took over the Lido area in 2013. The ministry gave KPIG a 90‑day grace period to comply with the recommendations, otherwise criminal or civil sanctions may apply. The KEK Lido project started in 2016 and partnered with the Trump Organization since 2019, with several projects only inaugurated in the second half of 2024 due to pandemic delays.
- $BIRD: Blue Bird President Director Adrianto Djokosoetono said the company targets double‑digit revenue growth in 2025, without providing further details. He also announced a significant expansion of the electric vehicle (EV) fleet, aiming to add 1,000 EV units in 2025, of which 500 units will be delivered in the first half of 2025. Bloomberg reports that Blue Bird's total fleet reached 23,000 vehicles at the end of 2023, with EVs accounting for 1% of the fleet.
- $PTBA: PT Bukit Asam, through its subsidiary MIND ID, announced a cooperation with Contemporary Amperex Technology Co. Ltd. (CATL) to develop synthetic graphite products for lithium‑ion battery manufacturing for EVs. PTBA is also conducting joint research with the National Research and Innovation Agency (BRIN) on a synthetic graphite prototype, with commercial production expected to start in 2028.
- $SIDO: Sido Muncul President Director David Hidayat purchased 905,700 SIDO shares at an average price of 575 rupiah per share on 4 February 2025, totaling approximately 521 million rupiah. After the transaction, his ownership rose from zero to 0.003%.
- $IMAS: Indomobil shareholder PT Sejahtera Raya Perkasa sold 40 million IMAS shares at an average price of 513 rupiah per share on 30 January 2025, totaling approximately 20.5 billion rupiah for a reverse repo. After the sale, its ownership decreased from 6.6% to 5.6%.
- $PGEO: Pertamina Geothermal Energy signed a joint study agreement with Pertamina Gas (Pertagas) to explore green hydrogen and green ammonia development. The cooperation includes technical information exchange and joint feasibility studies covering project viability, resource allocation, technology selection, and implementation timelines, to be carried out in geothermal areas managed by PGEO.
- $WSKT: Waskita Karya reported a new contract value of 9.6 trillion rupiah in 2024, a 43.2% YoY decline. Corporate Secretary Ermy Puspa Yunita said the new contract was secured amid the company's financial recovery and limited tender activity last year.
- Finance Minister Sri Mulyani on Thursday (6/2) denied rumors that the 13th and 14th civil servant salaries would be eliminated, stating that the rumors arose after President Prabowo Subianto instructed budget efficiency measures for the 2025 state and regional budgets to save up to 306.7 trillion rupiah.
- Public Works Minister Dody Hanggodo on Thursday (6/2) said at least 21 infrastructure projects will be delayed due to the 2025 budget efficiency measures, including connectivity, water resources, and residential area projects. He also noted that the development of the new capital city (IKN) has no progress because its budget remains blocked by Finance Minister Sri Mulyani following President Prabowo's efficiency instruction, reducing the ministry's 2025 budget from 81.38 trillion rupiah to 29.57 trillion rupiah.
- The Real Estate Indonesia association urged the government to accelerate the disbursement of the 2025 Housing Financing Liquidity Facility (FLPP) as developers of subsidized housing face cash‑flow difficulties. The government allocated 28.27 trillion rupiah for FLPP in 2025 to finance 220,000 subsidized houses, but is revising the scheme to a 50/50 split between the state budget and bank liquidity, up from the existing 75/25 split, to increase financing capacity to 330,000 houses.
- Health Minister Budi Gunadi Sadikin on Thursday (6/2) said the health partnership with the United States is suspended due to U.S. President Donald Trump's plan to streamline the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID). He warned that the suspension could burden Indonesia's efforts to combat HIV and tuberculosis, now the leading infectious disease cause of death globally in 2023, and noted that USAID has invested 800 million USD in Indonesia since 2020.
- The same minister announced a free health check‑up program to start on 10 February 2025, with a budget of about 3 trillion rupiah, targeting 220 million people in 2025, claiming it to be the largest health program ever implemented, surpassing COVID‑19 vaccination efforts.
- Investment and Downstream Minister Rosan Roeslani on Thursday (6/2) said the government aims to increase domestic automobile production to 2.5 million units by 2030, more than double the 2024 production of approximately 1.2 million units, as part of accelerating electric vehicle adoption to achieve net‑zero emissions by 2060.
- Narit Therdsteerasukdi, Secretary‑General of the Thailand Investment Board, told Reuters on Thursday (6/2) that Thailand plans to draft an initial strategic plan for the semiconductor industry within the next 90 days and is conducting a roadshow in the United States and Japan to attract investment. Thailand targets new semiconductor investment of up to 500 billion baht (approximately 14.8 billion USD) by 2029.
